name: Idiopathic Mesenteric Arteriolar Vasospasm Syndrome (IMAVS)
chief_complaint: Severe abdominal pain that comes and goes, worse after eating
symptoms: Weight loss due to fear of eating
physical_findings: Normal bowel sounds during asymptomatic periods

lab_results.CTA: Diffuse segmental vasospasm of mesenteric arterioles without occlusion

treatment: Intra-arterial vasodilator infusion during acute episodes
Psychological support for chronic pain management
prognosis: Variable; some patients respond well to medical therapy while others develop chronic pain syndrome
description: A rare vascular disorder characterized by recurrent, transient vasospasm of mesenteric arterioles without underlying atherosclerotic disease. The pathophysiology involves abnormal smooth muscle reactivity in small mesenteric vessels, leading to episodic ischemia. Diagnosis requires exclusion of other mesenteric pathologies and demonstration of dynamic vasospasm on angiography.
risk_factors: History of migraine or Raynaud's phenomenon
